articles.headline: A Gaza Truce Aids Both Sides. Until the Calculus Changes.
articles.snippet: Both Israel and Hamas are reaping benefits from the cease-fire, but as the hostage-for-prisoner exchanges continue, Israeli leaders may feel growing pressure to resume the war.
articles.abstract: Both Israel and Hamas are reaping benefits from the cease-fire, but as the hostage-for-prisoner exchanges continue, Israeli leaders may feel growing pressure to resume the war.
articles.lead_paragraph: The decision by Israel and Hamas to extend their brief truce has created short-term benefits for both sides but amplified uncertainty about how, when and whether Israel will continue its invasion of the Gaza Strip.

articles.headline: For Sports Illustrated, Report About Fake Authors Is Latest Stumble
articles.snippet: The venerable magazine has experienced management upheaval and staff complaints in recent years. Now there’s a question over who wrote product reviews on its site.
articles.abstract: The venerable magazine has experienced management upheaval and staff complaints in recent years. Now there’s a question over who wrote product reviews on its site.
articles.lead_paragraph: Three years ago, journalists at Sports Illustrated were worried that the venerable magazine’s new owners and operators were drastically lowering its standards. They noted reports of plagiarism, and worried about substandard writing and the use of freelance reporters with little due diligence. The journalists also wanted better pay, greater transparency during the hiring process and a guarantee that all work published on the Sports Illustrated website would be edited.
articles.byline: By Santul Nerkar and Kevin Draper

articles.headline: U.S. Debates How Much to Sever Electric Car Industry’s Ties to China
articles.snippet: Some firms argue that a law aimed at popularizing electric vehicles risks turning the United States into an assembly shop for Chinese-made technology.
articles.abstract: Some firms argue that a law aimed at popularizing electric vehicles risks turning the United States into an assembly shop for Chinese-made technology.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Biden administration has been trying to jump-start the domestic supply chain for electric vehicles so cleaner cars can be made in the United States. But the experience of one Texas company, whose plans to help make an all-American electric vehicle were upended by China, highlights the stakes involved as the administration finalizes rules governing the industry.
articles.byline: By Ana Swanson and Jack Ewing

articles.headline: Federal Law Requires a Choice: Marijuana or a Gun?
articles.snippet: Legal challenges are pending across the country against a federal law that prevents medical marijuana users from buying or owning firearms.
articles.abstract: Legal challenges are pending across the country against a federal law that prevents medical marijuana users from buying or owning firearms.
articles.lead_paragraph: For Vera Cooper, the time had come to buy a gun.

articles.headline: In a Shaky Oil Market, OPEC Has Bitter Decisions to Make
articles.snippet: Anticipating a drop in demand for 2024, major producers, led by Saudi Arabia, are trying to reduce supply.
articles.abstract: Anticipating a drop in demand for 2024, major producers, led by Saudi Arabia, are trying to reduce supply.
articles.lead_paragraph: These are tricky times for the world’s major oil producers: Prices are lower, the health of the global economy is uncertain, and, even as the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries tries to cut output, supplies from other producers, notably the United States, are growing.

articles.headline: In the West Bank, Release of Prisoners Deepens Support for Hamas
articles.snippet: Some people in the West Bank, where frustration with the Palestinian Authority has been simmering for years, believe Hamas and other armed groups are the only ones they can trust to protect them.
articles.abstract: Some people in the West Bank, where frustration with the Palestinian Authority has been simmering for years, believe Hamas and other armed groups are the only ones they can trust to protect them.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow live news updates on the Israel-Hamas war.
articles.byline: By Christina Goldbaum and Hiba Yazbek

articles.headline: G.M. to Cut Spending on Cruise Self-Driving Unit
articles.snippet: General Motors will “substantially lower spending” on autonomous vehicle efforts in 2024 after accidents with its self-driving taxis in San Francisco.
articles.abstract: General Motors will “substantially lower spending” on autonomous vehicle efforts in 2024 after accidents with its self-driving taxis in San Francisco.
articles.lead_paragraph: General Motors is slowing the expansion of its Cruise automated driving division and significantly cutting spending at the unit after suspending operations in response to growing safety concerns about its driverless cars.
articles.byline: By Neal E. Boudette and Yiwen Lu

articles.headline: Apple Is Doing Its Part to End Green Bubble Shaming. It’s Our Turn.
articles.snippet: While texting technology will soon get better, the “blue versus green bubble” disparity is far from over.
articles.abstract: While texting technology will soon get better, the “blue versus green bubble” disparity is far from over.
articles.lead_paragraph: For more than a decade, smartphone users everywhere have faced a major problem in how we communicate: the “green versus blue bubble” disparity.
